text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro said the second round of local elections did not show any real winner and this would be positive for the work of Italy's bicameral commission aimed at carrying out constitutional reforms. Scalfaro also harshly criticised the Northern League for its call for separatism and invited judges and magistrates to intervene (all).

* Hard left Communist Refoundation party leader Fausto Bertinotti said the fate of prime minister Romano Prodi's government depended on how it would handle the sensitive issue of welfare reforms (all).

* Treasury minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi repeated that Italy would reduce its budget deficit to three percent of gross domestic product in 1997 and announced he was aiming to reduce it below that level in 1998 (all).

* In an interview, foreign trade minister Augusto Fantozzi called for fiscal incentives to Italian exporters saying the sector showed serious signs the economy was suffering. Fantozzi said Italy needed to get itself ready to face world challenges like Spain was doing (La Repubblica).

* Insurance group Generali said its net consolidated attributable profit in 1996 rose to 1.437 trillion lire from 695 billion lire in 1995. The parent company announced an unchanged dividend per ordinary share of 375 lire/share for 1996 which, taking into account a free capital issue, saw the total company's dividend increase 10 percent (all).
* Telecommunication group Stet and Spanish utility Endesa said they each had 30.9 percent stake in a consortium bidding for Retevision, which will be Spain's second telephone operator (Sole 24 Ore).
* Galbani group said its sales fell by 7.5 percent in the last six months and it prepared a restructuring programme including over 1,000 cuts to personnel and 350 billion lire investments (all).
** Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
